Graphical abstract Supported metal catalysts of high intrinsic catalytic activities with significant mass and heat-transport properties are constructed via in situ synthesis based on the interfacial hydrothermal-oxidation/reductive-exolution (HO/RE) chemistry of Al metal substrates. The hydrothermal reaction of Al metal particles in an aqueous solution of Ni salt gives rise to the formation of NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure consisting of an Al core and a NiAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) shell with petal-like surface morphology. A reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al leads to exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH shell, developing fine Ni metal nanoparticles (NPs) with high surface dispersion and size uniformity. The mechanism of heterogeneous formation of MeAl-LDH (Me = hetero-metals) structures from Al metal substrate is suggested in detail. For CO2 methanation, the Ni/Al2O3@Al exhibits a three-fold greater turnover frequency (TOF) than the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method, indicating the marked intrinsic catalytic properties of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst. Keywords Supported metal catalyst CO2 methanation Heat and mass transport In situ synthesis Core-shell catalyst 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalysis practiced in industrial processes are complex, often coupled with the intrinsic surface reaction kinetics and the mass and heat transport through solid catalysts [1]. Metal catalysts, a major type of heterogeneous catalysts, are generally prepared by immobilizing catalytic metal nanoparticles (NPs) on metal-oxide supports via physical or chemical deposition, in which effective modulations of size, shape, and dispersion of the metal NPs are of marked importance for achieving high catalytic activity and selectivity. At the same time, transport of heat and mass through the solid catalysts are largely governed by the support properties, such as thermal conductivity, porosity, and pore dimensions. The heat and mass transport limitation can cause inefficient use of catalysts, which has detrimental effects on the product yield and selectivity and shortens the catalyst’s lifetime by deactivation. Previous theoretical and experimental studies have demonstrated the significance of mass and heat transport through heterogeneous catalysts for chemical reactions [2–9]. In the well-established application of metallic foams for catalyst preparation to improve heat conductivity, non-active high surface area metal oxides are initially deposited on the metal foam surface followed by introduction of the desired active metals or metal oxides [10]. However, the resulting structure is prone to degradation at the coated interface, and the method is hardly applicable for small particles and pellets in the general shapes or dimensions of the heterogeneous catalysts utilized in industry. In this work, we report a new design and highly efficient synthesis methodology of supported metal catalysts based on the in situ interfacial hydrothermal-oxidation/reductive-exolution (HO/RE) chemistry starting from zero-valent Al metal substrates. The overall approach is unique differing largely from the conventional ones such as synthesis methods based on impregnation or immobilization of active metals on metal oxide supports, because (i) the starting material is zero-valent Al metal substrates and (ii) the synthesis is based on the interfacial self-assembly of the MeAl (Me = heterometal atoms) layered double hydroxide (LDH) microstructures via heterogeneous dissolution-reconstruction of Al with Me ions in solution at the metal/solution interface. The synthesis is markedly simple, one-step, and highly efficient. As will be shown, interfacial hydrothermal oxidation of Al metal particles in an aqueous solution of Ni salts gives rise to the core-shell microarchitecture, which consists of a highly heat-conductive Al metal core densely covered with a NiAl-LDH shell, which will herein be called NiAl-LDH@Al. A controlled reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell results in the exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH shell, constructing finely dispersed Ni NPs on the Al2O3@Al core-shell (Ni/Al2O3@Al) with significant surface number density, size uniformity, catalytic activity, and stability that are hardly achievable by the conventional synthesis approaches. The high thermal conductivity of Al, which is more than one order of magnitude higher than that of the common metal oxides (Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, etc.), can afford for significantly enhanced heat conductivity of the catalysts, and the exceptional ductility of Al allows for extensive design flexibility of their architectures at the same time. LDHs are a class of anionic clay with a general formula of [M2+ 1-x M3+ x (OH)2]x+ (An−)x/n ∙ mH2O, where M2+ and M3+ are di- and trivalent metal cations uniformly dispersed in the structure at atomic level, An− is interlayer anions, and x is the surface charge determined by the ratio of two metal cations, M3+/(M2++M3+) [11]. LDHs have been widely used as catalysts and catalyst precursors for various reactions, such as selective oxidation of alcohols, methanol steam reforming, NOx reduction, and electrocatalytic water splitting reaction [11–14]. Although LDHs are generally synthesized in powder forms by co-precipitation of metal ions dissolved in solution, the LDH can be derived with unique composite microarchitectures with significant catalytic properties via interfacial hydrothermal oxidation of Al, as will be presented. The catalytic properties of Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell catalyst were investigated for the CO2 methanation reaction (CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O, ΔH0 298 K = −165 kJ mol−1). Methanation of CO2 has been a significant catalytic process for manufacturing of substitute natural gas (SNG) [15], as a potential pathway for production of valuable chemicals [16], and for storage of renewable electricity combined with water electrolysis [17]. Various catalysts with group VIII metals (Ni, Fe, Ru, Rh, Pd, Pt, Ir) have been reported for CO2 methanation, yet Ni catalysts are dominant in industrial processes because of the low cost and fair catalytic activities of Ni compared to those of the precious metals [18–20]. The Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts exhibit marked physicochemical and catalytic properties with high dispersion and uniformity of small Ni NPs developed in situ on the surface of the microstructure. The Al metal based interfacial HO/RE synthesis approach can be applied to other supported metal catalysts, and this is demonstrated with supported Co and Ni-Mg catalysts. The new and highly efficient design and synthesis approach based on the in situ HO/RE chemistry can provide extensive opportunities in the supported metal catalysts, providing significant catalytic and mass and heat transport properties that are markedly important in many catalytic processes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Scheme 1 shows the direct in situ synthesis procedure of a Ni catalyst supported on Al2O3@Al core-shell microstructure (Ni/Al2O3@Al). The synthesis proceeds in two simple sequential steps. In the first, NiAl-LDH is grown in situ on solid Al metal powder by interfacial hydrothermal reactions in an aqueous Ni salt solution to construct the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure. The resulting NiAl-LDH@Al is then directly reduced in H2 at elevated temperatures, which develops Ni NPs on the surface via exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH shell. Typically, 2.0 g of Al powder (Goodfellow, ϕ ≤ 25 μm) was placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 ml in volume) with 40 ml of 0.93 M aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O (Alfa Aesar). The hydrothermal synthesis was conducted at 473 K for 1 h, steadily maintaining the temperature by proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control. The resulting NiAl-LDH@Al powder was washed several times with deionized water, filtered, and dried at 393 K for 12 h. The final forms of the Ni catalysts were prepared through two different subsequent procedures, with or without an intermediate calcination step. The Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts were obtained by a reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al, either at 673 K for 4 h or at 823 K for 1 h in flowing 30 vol.% H2 (N2 balanced). In contrast, the Ni/NiAl2O4@Al catalyst was prepared through an intermediate calcination of the NiAl-LDH@Al at 823 K for 4 h, followed by a reduction at 823 K for 1 h. For comparative studies, a Ni catalyst (18 wt.% Ni loading) supported on γ-Al2O3 was prepared by the conventional incipient-wetness impregnation method. Briefly, 10 g of γ-Al2O3 powder (Alfa-Aesar) was impregnated with 4 ml of aqueous Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O solution (9.3 M). The resultant was dried at 393 K for 12 h in a convection oven, calcined in air at 823 K for 4 h, and reduced at 823 K for 1 h. The NiAl-LDH was synthesized on Al mesh (Nilaco Co.) by hydrothermal reaction in a 0.016 M aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O at 473 K for 1 h. The CoAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure was prepared by hydrothermal reaction of the Al power in a 0.23 M aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (Alfa Aesar) at 423 K for 3 h. The Co/Al2O3@Al catalyst was obtained by reduction of the CoAl-LDH@Al in H2 at 873 K for 1 h. The tri-metallic NiMgAl-LDH@Al core-shell was prepared by hydrothermal reaction of the Al powder in a 0.25 M aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O and Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O (Ni/Mg molar ratio = 0.4) at 473 K for 1 h. The sample was reduced in H2 at 773 K for 1 h. 2.2 Characterizations The surface morphology and elemental composition of the samples were characterized using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU-70, Hitachi) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). The structure and composition of the catalysts were characterized using a field emission transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM, Tecnai G2 F30ST) operated at 300 kV equipped with an EDS. The size distribution of metal NPs on the catalysts was characterized by image-analysis software (Image-pro-plus, Media Cybermetics). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the samples was obtained using a spectrometer (Ultima IV, Rigaku) with monochromic Cu-Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 40 mA (scan rate = 0.05° s−1). The overall elemental composition of the samples was obtained by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Optima 8300, Perkin Elmer). The surface atomic composition of the samples was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-ALPHA+, Thermo Fisher Scientific). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the samples was obtained in a volumetric unit (ASAP-2020, Micromeritics) after drying the samples in vacuum at 473 K for 4 h. The surface area was obtained by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The micropore volume and mesopore size distributions were estimated by t-plot and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the samples was carried out in an automated volumetric unit (AutoChem-II 2920, Micromeritics) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a mass spectrometer (Cirrus™ 2, MKS instruments). The TPR was carried out by raising the sample temperature from 298 K to 1100 K (ramp =10 K min−1) flowing 10 vol.% H2 (50 ml min−1, Ar balance). The H2 chemisorption amount on the samples was measured in a volumetric unit (ASAP-2020, Micromeritics) and used for metal dispersion and particle size characterization. 2.3 CO2 methanation CO2 methanation reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed tubular quartz-glass reactor (OD = 10, ID = 8, L =450 mm). The catalysts were diluted with a three-times weight amount of γ-Al2O3 to eliminate heat and mass transport limitation, pelletized (180–250 μm), and packed in a quartz-glass reactor using a fritted disk and quartz wool. The reactor was installed vertically in a PID-controlled electric tubular furnace. The reactor temperature was measured using a K-type thermocouple attached on the outside wall of the reactor at the catalyst-bed zone. The catalysts were reduced in flowing 30 vol.%-H2/N2 (100 ml min−1) either at 823 K for 1 h or 673 K for 4 h. The CO2 methanation reaction was carried out at atmospheric pressure, introducing a mixture of H2 and CO2 at a fixed H2/CO2 molar ratio of 10. Nitrogen was fed together with the reactants as an internal standard. The effluent was passed through a condenser maintained at 273.4 K and analyzed online using a gas chromatograph (7890A, Agilent) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of the Ni catalysts prepared via interfacial HO/RE chemistry of Al The Ni catalyst was constructed in situ on Al2O3@Al core-shell microstructure (Ni/Al2O3@Al) by a direct interfacial hydrothermal oxidation of Al particles followed by a reduction (Scheme 1). Fig. 1 a presents the SEM and TEM images of the Al particles (a1) and the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure (a1 inset, a2, and a3) obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of the Al particles at 473 K for 1 h. The SEM images (a1 inset and a2) clearly revealed the petal-like shell morphology of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell with a number of NiAl-LDH nanosheets (average thickness 150–200 nm, width 700–900 nm) densely grown on the Al with their ab-dimension (plane) perpendicular to the Al surface. The shape of NiAl-LDH nanosheets was similar to typical LDH crystallites that tends to have platelet morphology with the dimensions of ab-faces of the platelets are much larger than the dimension along the c-axis (thickness) of the platelets [21]. The TEM (a3) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) analysis (a3 inset) indicated that Ni atoms were homogeneously incorporated into the LDH structure without any noticeable phase segregation. The Ni content of the sample characterized by ICP-AES was 17.6 wt.%, which included the Al core in the analysis results. The actual Ni content on the NiAl-LDH nanosheets was significantly high. Table 1 shows the atomic composition of the NiAl-LDH shell characterized by XPS (the survey spectra are in Fig. S1). The Ni, Al, O, and N were observed with the Ni atomic content of 12.2 % (equivalent to 31.0 wt.%) and the Ni/Al atomic ratio of 0.67, in which the presence N was due to the nitrate anions incorporated into the interlayer galleries of the LDH structure for charge balancing. The composition and thickness of the NiAl-LDH shell could be modulated by changing the Ni ion concentration in the solution and hydrothermal reaction time [5]. A controlled reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell induced the formation of a number of Ni NPs on the Al2O3@Al core-shell via exolution of Ni atoms from the LDH nanosheets, maintaining the initial petal-like shell morphology. Fig. 1b displays the SEM and TEM images of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst obtained after a reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell in H2 at 673 K for 4 h. The SEM images (b1 and b2) clearly show that the microscopic petal-like shell morphology and the core-shell architecture remained the same even after the significant exolution of Ni ions from the LDH by the reduction. The TEM images (b3 and b4) reveal that a number of fine Ni NPs developed uniformly on the thin nanosheets that comprise the shell (thickness of the shell = ∼1.8 μm). The sharp electron diffraction (ED) pattern confirmed the formation of metallic Ni NPs by the reductive exolution of Ni atoms (b3 inset). The sizes of Ni NPs measured by TEM fell mostly within 3–5 nm with a sharp unimodal size distribution. The surface number density of Ni NPs was markedly high (2.7 × 1015 Ni-NPs m−2), indicating a significant loading and high dispersion of Ni NPs on the surface of catalyst via the reductive exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH shell. This value, as will be compared in Fig. 4, was about two-fold greater than the surface number density of Ni NPs on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (1.4 × 1015 Ni-NPs m−2) prepared by the conventional incipient-wetness impregnation at the similar Ni loading amount. The elemental composition on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst characterized by XPS (Table 1) indicated that the interlayer nitrate anions were completely removed from the LDH shell by the reduction treatment at 673 K. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of (a) NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell, (b) Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst reduced at 673 K, and (c) Ni/Al2O3@Al reduced at 823 K. The NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell exhibited the sharp characteristic peaks of a typical LDH structure, which can be indexed to a hexagonal lattice with R3m rhombohedral symmetry [22]. The lattice parameters (a = 2d110, c = d003 + 2d006 + 3d009) [23] and crystallite sizes (a and c lattice directions) of the NiAl-LDH calculated by the Scherrer equation are shown in Table 2 . Along with the SEM analysis results which clearly show the uniform formation of LDH shell on the surface of Al particles, the superposition of sharp characteristic peaks of Al metal (2θ = 38.5, 44.7, 65.1, 78.2, 82.5°, ICDD#01-071- 3760) with those of the NiAl-LDH indicates the formation of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure. The small and broad peaks that appeared at 2θ of 14.6, 28.0, 49.3, and 63.8° indicated that boehmite (ICDD#01-074-2895) was formed to some extent in the shell by the hydrothermal reactions. The XRD pattern of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst reduced at 673 K (Fig. 2b) is largely different from that of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell. Upon the reduction of NiAl-LDH@Al at 673 K, the NiAl-LDH peaks vanished completely, and the metallic Ni peaks appeared (2θ = 44.6, 52.0 and 76.6° ICDD#01-070-0989) on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst. The results confirm the reductive exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH nanosheets, which developed finely dispersed Ni NPs on the surface, as revealed from the TEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) results (Fig. 1b3 and 1b4). The average size of Ni NPs estimated by the Scherrer equation was 3.7 nm, in excellent agreement with that observed by TEM (Fig. 1b4) which revealed the sharp unimodal size distribution of the Ni NPs. The relative reduction amount of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH shell characterized by H2-TPR was about 27 % (Fig. S2). A reduction at a higher temperature of 823 K increased the relative Ni reduction amount to ∼85 %. However, this accompanied a considerable increase in the size of Ni NPs (6.2–6.6 nm) as revealed from the TEM (Fig. S3) and XRD results (Fig. 2c) with scarification of the surface area and porosity of the catalysts (Fig. 3 ). The XRD spectra of the Ni/Al2O3@Al reduced at 823 K exhibited much sharper characteristic Ni metal peaks than those of the Ni/Al2O3@Al reduced at 673 K, indicating that the crystal size of Ni NPs increased as the reduction temperature increased. It is evident from the results that the reductive exolution of Ni atoms led to a transformation of the NiAl-LDH to mostly porous alumina, preserving the initial nanosheet morphology with petal-like shell architecture. The crystalline degree of the resulting alumina seems to be low, as deduced from the XRD results. The crystalline NiO (2θ = 37.3, 43.3, and 62.9°, ICDD#01-075-0269) and spinel NiAl2O4 (2θ = 37.0, 45.0 and 65.5°, ICDD#01-078-1601) phases were developed during the thermal reduction to some extent. These crystalline phases could be reduced only at temperatures well above 873 K (Fig. S2). Fig. 3 displays (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and (b) BJH pore-size distribution of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell and the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts reduced at 673 and 823 K. All these samples exhibit the type IV isotherm typical for mesoporous materials with the characteristics of the H3 type hysteresis, demonstrating the presence of parallel slit-shaped pores attributed to the layered structure of the NiAl-LDH nanosheets. The isotherms of Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts show greater surface areas and pore volumes than the NiAl-LDH@Al because of the removal of nitrate anions from the inter-laminar region of the NiAl-LDH by the reduction at elevated temperatures. The TPR and mass spectrometry (MS) analysis indicated that the nitrate anions were released from the NiAl-LDH dominantly in the form of NO starting from 457 to 668 K with H2 consumption (Fig. S2), which was in good agreement with the reduction characteristics of NiAl-LDHs reported in the literature [24]. It was notable that the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst reduced at 673 K showed a higher N2 adsorption volume and surface area than the sample reduced at 823 K, indicating that the reduction at 823 K accompanied collapse of the pore structures to some extent. This could be confirmed from the broadening of the pore-size distribution with an increase in the reduction temperature (Fig. 3b). The NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell showed a sharp pore-size distribution centered around 3.9 nm, while the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts showed a significant development of micropores (pore sizes< 2 nm) attributed to the micro-voids formed by the exolution of Ni atoms from the LDH structure. Table 3 displays the BET surface area, average pore size, and pore volume of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell and the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst. Markedly, the Ni/Al2O3@Al exhibited a surface area (SA = 215 m2 g−1) more than three-fold greater, and a micropore volume (Vmicro = 0.12 cm3 g−1) one order of magnitude greater, than those of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell (SA = 64 m2 g−1, Vmicro = 0.01 cm3 g−1). The high surface area of the Ni/Al2O3@Al than that of the NiAl-LDH@Al is mainly attributed to the removal of nitrate anions and H2O from the interlayer of NiAl-LDH and the development of micropores via exolution of Ni ions from the LDH structure by the reduction at high temperature. Such increases in the surface area of LDHs by heat treatment was reported in the literature, which was due to elimination of the charge balancing anions and H2O presented in the interlayer of LDH layers [24]. It is worthy to mention that the formation of micropores was not observed when the NiAl-LDH@Al was treated at high temperatures under inert or oxidation atmosphere, in which the reductive exolution of Ni species from the NiAl-LDH did not occur (Fig. S4). Therefore, it can be deduced that the one order magnitude greater micropore volume on the Ni/Al2O3@Al was mainly attributed to the reductive exolution of Ni from the NiAl-LDH by the reduction treatment. The small particle size, high surface number density (2.7 × 1015 Ni-NPs m−2), and uniformity of Ni NPs on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst confirmed the significance of the interfacial HO/RE based in situ synthesis of the supported Ni catalysts from the Al metal substrate. The average size of Ni NPs estimated from the amount of the H2 chemisorption and the Ni reduction of the sample was 2.0 nm (Table 4 ), which was about half the size found by the TEM and XRD analysis, indicating markedly high dispersion of Ni on the catalysts. A trade-off existed between the extent of reductive exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH and the physicochemical properties of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts. The reduction of NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell at 823 K provided a three-fold increase in the relative Ni reduction amount (∼85 %) over that reduced at 673 K (∼27 %), but the H2 chemisorption amount on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst decreased by ∼15 % due to 2–3 times increase in the size of Ni NPs (Table 4) and ∼20 % decrease of the surface area (Table 3). It is evident from the results that there is an optimum range of the reduction temperature of NiAl-LDH to achieve high Ni surface loading and dispersion, retaining the high surface area and porosity. An intermediate calcination of the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell at an elevated temperature (823 K) led to a transformation of the NiAl-LDH to the mixed crystalline phases of spinel NiAl2O4, nickel aluminates, and nickel oxides as revealed by the XRD results (Fig. S5). The SEM and TEM analysis revealed that the overall petal-like shell morphology and core-shell structure was preserved, but the spinel NiAl2O4 phase, segregated as the nodules, dominantly formed throughout the shell structure (Fig. S6). For comparison, a Ni catalyst (18 wt.% Ni loading) supported on γ-Al2O3 was prepared by the conventional incipient-wetness method. Fig. 4 displays (a) TEM image and (b) XRD pattern of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The TEM images clearly exhibit that Ni NPs (average size =7.4 nm) on the Ni/Al2O3 were significantly larger than those on the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell catalysts with a broad size distribution, non-uniform spatial placement, and low surface particle density (1.4 × 1015 Ni-NPs m−2). Table 4 compares the average size of Ni NPs obtained by the TEM, XRD, and H2 chemisorption analysis on the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell and the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. The H2 chemisorption amount on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst was about twice that on the Ni/Al2O3 attributed to the high dispersion of Ni NPs, even though the Ni surface loading amount on the Ni/Al2O3@Al was only about one third of that on the Ni/Al2O3. As the TEM analysis revealed (Fig. 1), the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst presented about 2-fold greater surface number density of Ni NPs (2.7 × 1015 Ni-NPs m-2) than the Ni/Al2O3 (1.4 × 1015 Ni-NPs m-2). The surface number density of Ni NPs on the Ni/Al2O3@Al was markedly high, considering that the Ni/Al2O3@Al had a higher BET surface area (Table 3) than the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with a lower net amount of Ni metal exposed on the surface by the reduction. It is clear from the results that the high surface number density of Ni NPs on the Ni/Al2O3@Al was attributed to the significantly high dispersion of Ni on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst. The Ni ions are atomically distributed in the NiAl-LDH, and its reductive exolution give rise to high dispersion of Ni on the catalyst surface, resulting in the markedly high surface number density of Ni NPs on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst. 3.2 Intrinsic catalytic properties of Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst for CO2 methanation The catalytic properties of the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell catalysts were studied for CO2 methanation and compared them with those of the conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The CO2 methanation over Ni catalysts has been reported to be structure sensitive favoring small Ni particle sizes, in which stepped sites [25] and the adsorption strength of the reaction intermediate CO species [26] are considered to play kinetically significant roles. However, sintering of Ni NPs can occur under methanation conditions even at relatively low temperatures via surface diffusion of the mobile nickel subcarbonyl species [27]. The supported metal catalysts obtained by reductive exolution can provide high surface number density of metal NPs, nearly monodispersed particle-size distribution, and enhanced thermal stability against sintering, because the metal NPs are socketed on the support matrix with increased metal-support interaction [28–30]. The petal-like shell morphology with the fine Ni NPs dispersed on the thin nanosheets comprising the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell microstructure also can topologically retard the aggregation of Ni NPs and provide facile transport of reactant and product species through the catalyst microstructure. The marked effects of enhanced heat transport through the metal-ceramic core-shell catalysts were demonstrated in our previous studies with Rh/MgAl2O4@Al catalysts for the endothermic glycerol steam reforming (C3H8O3 + 3H2O → 3CO2 + 7H2, ΔH°298 K =128 kJ mol−1), in which about one order magnitude greater heat conductivity of the core-shell catalyst resulted in ∼50 % higher glycerol conversion than that on the conventional Rh/MgAl2O4 catalyst at intensive reaction condition [5]. Herein, we focus our studies on the interfacial HO/RE based in situ synthesis of the core-shell catalysts and the modulation of intrinsic catalytic properties, rather than on the effects of the heat and mass transport enhancement through the catalysts. Fig. 5 a presents CO2 conversion by the methanation on the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell and the conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. The CO product selectivity on the catalysts are shown in the inset Fig. The catalysts were packed in the reactor after dilution with inert γ-Al2O3 to eliminate heat and mass transfer limitation (details are in the experimental section) for measurements of the intrinsic catalytic properties. The reactions on these catalysts dominantly produced CH4 with slight amounts of CO (< 2 %). Formation of other higher hydrocarbons or oxidated hydrocarbons were not observed. The results clearly showed that the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst reduced at 673 K exhibited much higher CO2 conversions than the conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The catalytic activity of the Ni/Al2O3@Al was particularly high at low temperatures (< 550 K), displaying about 3–4 times greater CO2 conversion than those on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. This was mainly attributed to the markedly small Ni NPs of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst with high surface number density, which would provide catalytically preferable active sites with low-coordination Ni atoms on the Ni NPs surface. The CO selectivity on the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts was much lower than that on the Ni/Al2O3 in favor of the CH4 production. The CO2 conversion turnover frequency (TOF) on these catalysts was obtained at temperatures of 523 and 548 K at similar CO2 conversion level (10–28%) varying the reactant space velocities (39,000–170,000 ml h−1 gcat−1). The results shown in Fig. 5b reveal that the CO2 methanation on these catalysts was structure sensitive, displaying a considerable rise of TOF value with a decrease of the size of Ni NPs on the catalysts. The TOF on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at 523 K (3.2 × 10-2 s−1) was similar to the values reported on Ni/Al2O3 in the literature at similar reaction conditions (1.3 × 10-2 s−1) [31]. Markedly, the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell catalyst exhibited a TOF (2.2 × 10−1 s−1) about three-fold greater than that of the Ni/Al2O3 (7.9 × 10-2 sec−1) at 548 K, demonstrating the significant intrinsic catalytic activity of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst obtained by the interfacial HO/RE of Al metal substrate. Fig. 6 shows a) time on stream CO2 conversion and b) CO selectivity on the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell and the reference Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for a continuous 200 h reaction at 573 K (space velocity = 78,800 ml h−1 gcat −1). The TEM images of the fresh and the spent Ni/Al2O3@Al catalysts are displayed in Fig. 6c. It is notable that the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst is highly stable for CO2 methanation, exhibiting only ∼ 3 % initial decrease in the CO2 conversion for 200 h reaction in the stream. The Ni/Al2O3 also show high stability for the reaction, but the CO2 conversion is much lower than that of the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell catalyst with about 3 times higher CO selectivity. The TEM images of the fresh (Fig. 6c1) and the spent Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst (Fig. 6c2) reveal only a slight increase in the sizes of Ni NPs after the reaction, agreeing well with the steady CO2 conversion observed for the extended time of the reaction. These results collectively confirm the significant catalytic activity and stability of the Ni/Al2O3@Al core-shell catalysts obtained by the direct synthesis via the interfacial HO/RE of Al metal particles in the solution. 3.3 Generality of the interfacial HO/RE synthesis for supported metal catalysts The Al based in situ interfacial synthesis allows for fabrication of supported Ni catalysts in complex shapes and architectures with various shapes and dimensions, starting from a pre-designed Al metal substrate as the template and the Al source. Fig. 7 a shows the SEM images of the NiAl-LDH developed on Al mesh by the hydrothermal oxidation reaction. Clearly, a number of NiAl-LDH nanosheets densely grown perpendicular to the surface of Al mesh can be seen that comprise the petal-like surface morphology similar to those observed on the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell. The results indicate that the in situ interfacial HO/RE synthesis approach can offer high spatial resolution, allowing for construction of sophisticated catalyst architectures at micrometer scales. It is important to note that the interfacial HO/RE synthesis methodology can be extended to other metal catalysts by varying hetero-metal (Me) ions in the hydrothermal oxidation step. Fig. 7b shows the CoAl-LDH@Al core-shell and the Co/Al2O3@Al catalyst obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of Al powder in an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O and its reduction in H2. The SEM and EDS results of the CoAl-LDH@Al clearly show the formation of a number of CoAl-LDH nanosheets, constructing the core-shell microstructure with a high Co atomic content (14 %) in the CoAl-LDH shell. The TEM and XRD results on the Co/Al2O3@Al catalyst reveal the fine Co NPs formed on the surface by the reductive exolution of Co atoms from the CoAl-LDH nanosheets. The average size of Co NPs characterized by TEM and XRD was about 14 nm, exhibiting a high dispersion of Co NPs over the shell surface. The acid-base surface properties of supports often have considerable roles on the activity and selectivity of supported metal catalysts. Fig. 7c1 shows the tri-metallic NiMgAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure obtained by hydrothermal reaction of the Al particles in a mixed aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O and Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O. The EDS results confirm the incorporation of Ni and Mg ions in the NiMgAl-LDH structure (Ni = 8 atomic %, Mg = 2 atomic %). The atomic content and ratio of Ni and Mg in the NiMgAl-LDH shell could be modulated by the hydrothermal reaction time and the concentration of metal ions in the synthesis solution. The incorporation of non-reducible Mg in the support structure can introduce basic surface properties on the catalyst, improving the stability against sintering and coking [32,33]. The TEM image (Fig. 7c2) reveals the Ni NPs developed on the catalyst by the reductive exolution of Ni from the NiMgAl-LDH shell. The XRD results confirm the formation of Ni NPs on the structure. The average size of Ni NPs characterized by TEM and XRD analysis was about 5 nm, revealing the fine dispersion of Ni NPs with a high surface number density and size uniformity. These results suggest that the in situ interfacial HO/RE synthesis methodology can be extended to other supported metal catalysts by varying the active metal cations in the synthesis solution. 3.4 Mechanism of the formation of MeAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructures Typically, LDHs are prepared in crystalline powder forms by homogeneous co-precipitation process in precursor metal salt solution at elevated pH condition [34]. The hydrothermal formation and growth of MeAl-LDH shell or film on zero-valent Al metal substrates can be described as a heterogeneous process, which would depend on the phase thermodynamics of the materials, the relative dissolution and precipitation kinetics of the Al substrate to the divalent hetero-metal (Me) ions in the solution, and the diffusion of the Me ions through the growing shell layer. Fig. 8 describes a probable mechanism of heterogeneous hydrothermal formation of NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure from zero-valent Al metal in an aqueous solution of Ni salt. It has been reported that the hydrothermal reactions of Al metal substrate transform the surface of Al to Al hydroxides mostly in the form of boehmite or pseudo-boehmite even at neutral pH without an addition of any reagents [35,36]. The process is heterogeneous, and the reaction occurs at the H2O/Al interface with a gradual moving of the reaction-front (interface) to the interior Al substrate with a thickening of the boehmite shell. The bonding between the shell and the Al core is covalent and strong, providing significant mechanical and physicochemical stability. In this work, the Ni2+ cations do not homogeneously precipitate to Ni hydroxides in the precursor solution because of the high precipitation pH of Ni2+ cations, whereas Al hydroxides forms on the Al surface by the heterogeneous dissolution-precipitation of Al with subsequent crystallization into boehmite or pseudoboehmite structures (The hydrothermal oxidation step in Fig. 8). In the second step, the Ni2+ and NO3 − ions diffuse into the Al hydroxides from the solution, which also drive the release of Al3+ cations from the boehmite layer and subsequent coprecipitation with Ni2+ cations. The release of Al3+ cations from the boehmite or pseudo-boehmite can be promoted by adsorption of Ni2+, as it has been reported for alumina with adsorption of heterometal cations such as Ni2+ and Zn2+ [37]. This would lead to the development of the supersaturated region abundant with Ni2+ and Al3+ cations, where the NiAl-LDH crystal seeds begin to form by in situ process with the electrostatic intercalation of NO3 − anions into the interlayer galleries for compensating the positive charges of the LDH sheets (The heterogeneous nucleation step in Fig. 8). Therefore, the crystal seeding and growth of the NiAl-LDH propagates from the exterior to the interior, establishing the strong NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure. The highly oriented growth of LDH nanosheets with their ab crystallographic dimension perpendicular to the Al surface (Fig. 1) can be explained by the evolutionary selection mechanism first proposed by van der Drift for vapor phase deposition of PbO layer [38]. Initially, the NiAl-LDH seeds formed in the supersaturated region can grow in all possible directions, but their probability of survival will be determined by the different crystallographic growth rates of the individual crystals. Because the growth of NiAl-LDH crystals is anisotropic with much faster rates in the ab direction than the c direction, the vertical growth of the individual NiAl-LDH nanosheets avoiding collisions between the growing crystals is favored with a great probability of survival, while other orientations will gradually die out over the repetition of seeding and growth process. The vertical orientation of the NiAl-LDH nanosheets is also highly favorable for diffusion of Ni2+ and NO3− ions through the thickening NiAl-LDH shell (The LDH crystal growth step in Fig. 8). These collectively result in the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure, displaying the petal-like surface morphology with a number of NiAl-LDH nanosheets oriented vertically to the Al surface. The results in this work suggest that the Al-based in situ synthesis of supported metal catalysts via the interfacial HO/RE chemistry can provide significant new opportunities in the catalyst design and the modulation of catalytic and transport properties at the same time that are of marked importance in many catalytic reaction processes. The potential other application areas may include highly endothermic Fischer-Tropsch and natural gas reforming reactions, and exothermic CO oxidation reactions, etc. 4 Conclusions Interfacial hydrothermal reaction of Al metal particles in an aqueous solution of Ni ions led to in situ development of crystalline NiAl-LDH on Al surface, resulting in the NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell metal-ceramic microstructure consisting of the Al metal core and the NiAl-LDH shell. A controlled reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al resulted in the reductive exolution of Ni ions from the NiAl-LDH nanosheet, which led to the formation of small Ni NPs finely dispersed on the shell surface. The Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst derived from the NiAl-LDH@Al exhibited marked intrinsic catalytic properties for CO2 methanation attributed to the fine dispersion of Ni NPs with high surface number density and uniformity. The in situ synthesis of supported metal catalysts based on the interfacial HO/RE chemistry can be extended to various metal catalysts as shown with the CoAl-LDH@Al and tri-metallic NiMgAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructures and the formation of catalytic metal NPs on the surface by reductive exolution. The mechanism of formation of MeAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructures can be described as heterogeneous interfacial process which proceeds with Al surface oxidation, crystallization of the LDH seeds in the supersaturated region of the Al surface with diffusion of Me cations, and MeAl-LDH crystal growth in the form of thin nanosheets with a high spatial orientation of their ab plane perpendicular to the surface. This new design and highly efficient synthesis approach of supported metal catalysts can afford for significant catalytic and transport properties that are of critical importance in many catalytic reaction processes. coredata.dc:description: Supported metal catalysts of high intrinsic catalytic activities with significant mass and heat-transport properties are constructed via in situ synthesis based on the interfacial hydrothermal-oxidation/reductive-exolution (HO/RE) chemistry of Al metal substrates. The hydrothermal reaction of Al metal particles in an aqueous solution of Ni salt gives rise to the formation of NiAl-LDH@Al core-shell microstructure consisting of an Al core and a NiAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) shell with petal-like surface morphology. A reduction of the NiAl-LDH@Al leads to exolution of Ni atoms from the NiAl-LDH shell, developing fine Ni metal nanoparticles (NPs) with high surface dispersion and size uniformity. The mechanism of heterogeneous formation of MeAl-LDH (Me = hetero-metals) structures from Al metal substrate is suggested in detail. For CO2 methanation, the Ni/Al2O3@Al exhibits a three-fold greater turnover frequency (TOF) than the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method, indicating the marked intrinsic catalytic properties of the Ni/Al2O3@Al catalyst.
